title: Synthetic Recap
body:
AP SPORTS

LOS ANGELES – In a season filled with bright young stars, Shaquille O’Neal authored a performance of historic and brutal force.

O’Neal, the Lakers’ colossal center, delivered a superhuman stat line, pouring in 48 points, grabbing 14 rebounds, and swatting away 3 shots to power Los Angeles to a decisive 122-107 road victory over the Washington Bullets.

From the opening tip, the game was a one-man demolition project. The Bullets had no answer for O’Neal’s combination of size, power, and agility in the paint. He was unstoppable, methodically dismantling the Washington defense with thunderous dunks and soft-touch finishes off the glass. Every possession was a referendum on his dominance, as the Lakers wisely and repeatedly fed the beast.

While the Bullets received valiant efforts from Chris Webber (22 points, 10 rebounds) and Juwan Howard (20 points, 12 rebounds), their production paled in comparison to the singular storm they were trying to weather. O’Neal’s 48-point outburst wasn't just high scoring; it was an event, a relentless display of physical supremacy that left the Capital Centre crowd in awe.

The victory was a showcase of the Lakers’ simple, yet devastating, blueprint for success: get the ball to Shaq. With their franchise player operating at an otherworldly level, the Lakers’ supporting cast, including Eddie Jones’s 18 points, played their roles perfectly, providing supplementary offense that made the lead insurmountable.

On this night, the final score was merely a formality. The real story was the 48 points next to one name in the box score—a number that echoes through the annals of the game and serves as a terrifying reminder of Shaquille O’Neal’s prime dominance.
